conclusion: The solution aims to determine the direction of acceleration during the 0 to 10 seconds interval using the velocity-time graph of the skydiver's vertical movement.
The y-axis of the graph shows velocity in m/s, the x-axis shows time in seconds, and the curve represents how the skydiver's vertical velocity changes over time.

Acceleration is the rate of change of velocity with respect to time. On a v-t graph: positive slope indicates positive acceleration, negative slope indicates negative acceleration, and zero slope indicates zero acceleration.
From 0 to 10 seconds, the curve starts at v = 0 m/s at t = 0, increases gradually, with the slope initially being steeper, then decreases over time, and reaches approximately v = 20 m/s at t = 10s.
For vertical movement of a falling object, downward is conventionally taken as positive.
The velocity increases from 0 to 20 m/s, indicating the skydiver is accelerating downward.
During 0-10 seconds, the slope of the v-t graph is positive, meaning the acceleration is positive.
The tangent line shown in red in the second image confirms the positive slope of the v-t graph during 0-10 seconds.
Since the velocity is increasing in the downward direction, the acceleration is also in the downward direction.
During the 0 to 10 seconds interval, the acceleration is in the downward direction due to gravity, as the skydiver gradually approaches terminal velocity.
